newsitem.title: USA: Indiana Gov. signs $233 mln tax relief package.
newsitem.headline: Indiana Gov. signs $233 mln tax relief package.

text.p: Indiana Gov. Frank O'Bannon has signed legislation giving increased tax credits and deductions of nearly $233 million over a three-year period.
O'Bannon on Wednesday signed a bill that increases the homestead credit for homeowners from 4 percent to 10 percent for the years 1998 through 2001, he announced in a news release.

The law also increased deductions for dependants from $1,000 to $1,500 for 1997 through 2000 and provided earned income tax deductions for working parents who earn less than $12,000 annually for the same period.
Indiana legislators have not completed work on the state's biennium budget.
O'Bannon has called for a special budget session on June 2, but would set an earlier meeting if legislative leaders reach a compromise before that, a spokesman said.
The lack of a budget has stalled financing plans for an Indianapolis convention center expansion and a new arena for the Indiana Pacers basketball team.
O'Bannon vetoed bills permitting increases in the hotel/motel tax, rental car tax and broadening a ticket tax for the convention center expansion after legislators failed to reach a budget accord.
The governor will sign bills for the convention center when legislators reach a budget agreement, spokesman Steve Campbell said.
